hero.kicker: Industrial heritage · Places of encounter · Knowledge transfer
hero.lead: CoStructure develops modular, publicly accessible cubes that make industrial heritage tangible, create low-threshold learning opportunities and offer spaces for encounter, creativity and technical exploration. The project aims to make industrial heritage more visible, accessible and diverse – and to encourage people of all ages to discover new perspectives in technology, design and urban space, and to find their own paths into future urban fields.
hero.ctaPrimary: Explore the cubes on the map
hero.news: Free workshops, talks, and school modules in public spaces – starting in fall 2026 in Berlin.

project.title: What is CoStructure?
project.subtitle: Spaces that connect past and future
project.imageAlt: CoStructure Cube at an industrial site in Berlin
project.intro:
CoStructure transforms places with industrial history into small, open spaces for curiosity and encounter. The cubes are flexible micro-spaces: part furniture, part meeting point, part learning environment. They reveal what often remains hidden within the buildings – stories, materials, ideas – and invite people to become part of them.


Here you can draw, build, experiment, observe, talk, listen, take part – without registration, without barriers. The cubes create islands in everyday life: for school classes and strolls, for neighbourhoods and spontaneous visits, for everyone who wants to experience the city differently.

No prior knowledge necessary
project.forWhom: For neighbourhoods, school classes, people on walks, people with children, people who need a break – and anyone curious about the city beyond shopping streets.
project.where: At places with history: gasworks, railway sites, factories, industrial grounds. The cubes make industrial backdrops tangible in everyday life – not as museums, but as living places that can be used again.

why.title: Why CoStructure was created
why.hook: Did you know that most industrial buildings were designed by men – not because they had better ideas, but because women were simply not allowed to study for decades? And did you know that the many women who kept factories, workshops and telecommunication offices running are barely mentioned in the official narratives of industrial heritage?
why.p1: For over a hundred years, women were barely allowed to work as architects, engineers or technicians. Still, they achieved remarkable things: from inventions essential to everyday life to scientific discoveries like those of Marie Curie. Yet these stories are rarely told – and in urban space, they are almost invisible.
why.p2: CoStructure steps in here: the cubes bring forgotten perspectives back into everyday life. They make industrial heritage visible not only as a façade but as a network of people and stories – from workers, tinkerers, researchers, neighbours. And they show girls and young women that technology, design and urban space are not closed clubs but fields they can shape naturally.
why.list1: that behind brick façades there are people – not just machines.
why.list2: that women have always played a role in industry, technology and urban design – even if they were rarely mentioned.
why.list3: that children, young people and adults today can connect their own visions of the future to these places.
why.p3: Today there is more visibility, more opportunity, more voices. Yet women remain underrepresented in many technical and design fields. The cubes invite us not only to name this gap but to close it together – through learning, exchange and rediscovering stories that have been pushed to the margins.
why.p4: CoStructure understands industrial heritage as a gender perspective in urban space: not didactic, but inviting. The cubes are places to pause, listen, marvel, participate – and maybe think: "True… I never considered that before." That’s where change begins.

cube.title: What do the cubes look like – and what are they for?
cube.subtitle: Two formats, one principle: open, accessible spaces for exchange, learning and observing the city.
cube.imageAlt: Interior or exterior view of a CoStructure cube next to industrial architecture
cube.contentTop: CoStructure works with two cube types that connect to industrial sites but function differently:
cube.permanentContent: Robust, weatherproof and architecturally anchored. Steel frames, mesh panels, green roofs and open sides turn them into small, clear micro-spaces: a place to sit, draw, listen or simply breathe. Inside: rotating information – posters, QR codes, photos. Outside: seating cubes and small platforms for conversations and mini-events. They remain permanently at one location and make industrial settings tangible in everyday life.
cube.mobileContent: A cube on wheels: a compact trailer that unfolds on site into a sheltered space. The sides fold up, the roof forms, and underneath appears a temporary meeting point – for workshops, walks, school groups or spontaneous activities. Lightweight seating modules, mobile poster surfaces and low-energy lighting make it adaptable and quick to use. It appears wherever something is happening.
cube.contentBottom: Both cube formats bring industrial heritage out into the urban space – as open places without entry barriers, inviting people of all ages to discover something new.

about.projectDescription:
Berlin is shaped by industry. Many former industrial buildings can still be found outside typical industrial zones. Many of these structures appear impressive but also closed-off: monumental, dark, inaccessible or isolated. Historically, they were planned and built almost exclusively by men. Women appear in this history mostly as workers. Yet it is their labour, hours and strength that kept these places running.


This is where the CoStructure cube comes in: an open, accessible place of encounter right beside historic industrial buildings. It invites visitors to rediscover industrial heritage from an expanded perspective. Alongside this, an interactive map presents locations, contexts and often overlooked stories. Together, they form a digital-physical project that makes industrial heritage more inclusive.
about.relevance:
Industrial heritage is a central part of Berlin’s history – but one told mostly from a male perspective. Women, queer people and other marginalised groups are barely represented. Even today, many industrial areas feel functional, rough and unsafe at night – rarely like places that serve everyone equally.

Why is this relevant? Spaces are never neutral. They signal belonging or exclusion. Marginalised groups remain largely invisible in industrial history. Industrial sites are often perceived as unsafe. And when historic buildings are repurposed, gender perspectives are rarely considered. The cube and the map address these gaps and reopen these spaces.
about.currentStatus:
The digital map already highlights selected industrial heritage sites and connects them to historical contexts. Filters, time layers and story elements make the content accessible and interactive.

The cube concept is being developed in parallel: a light, modular structure that prioritises openness, visibility and inclusion. Next steps include material specification, selecting a pilot location and integrating personal stories.
about.benefits:
For urban space:

• Activation of neglected or unsafe places
• Improved quality of stay and visibility
• Low-threshold meeting point
• New attention for historic buildings

For society:

• Visibility of women’s labour and history
• Awareness of gender-sensitive urban planning
• Strengthening social participation
• Public space for everyone

For visitors:

• Easy access to knowledge
• Safe, open place to stay
• Space for exhibitions, workshops and encounters
• A sign that the city belongs to everyone
about.implementation:
Implementation consists of two interconnected parts:

1. The cube:
• modular, light and adaptable
• open structure with clear sightlines and lighting
• materials referencing industrial heritage
• barrier-free and safe
• space for information, exhibitions and encounter

2. The digital map:
• shows industrial heritage sites
• connects historical and gender-related content
• offers filters by time, use and theme
• continuously expandable
• links digital and physical urban experiences
about.knowledgeTransfer:
The cube is an open place for learning and encounter. It conveys knowledge in a low-threshold, accessible and everyday way – not as a museum.

Content includes:
- history of Berlin’s industrial heritage
- roles of women and marginalised groups
- basics of gender-sensitive urban planning
- visible and invisible labour
- perceptions of safety and space
- neighbourhood perspectives
about.stories:
Stories are at the heart of this project. They reveal how many perspectives have been missing in industrial heritage.

They include:
- women who kept factories running during wartime
- women whose labour was never documented
- everyday experiences of women around industrial sites
- voices from the neighbourhood
- today’s view of industrial areas as fascinating or unsafe
- examples of successful and failed reuse

These stories reveal what industrial heritage often hides: that these places were full of life – and can be again.

mobile.title: Mobile CoStructure cubes
mobile.intro: Mobile CoStructure cubes travel to your site for a weekend, a week or a festival. They bring exhibition, workshop space and meeting point together in one compact format – usable both inside and outside.
mobile.ctaTitle: Bring a CoStructure cube to your site
mobile.ctaText: You have a site, festival, courtyard or public square where a CoStructure cube could work well? Together we can design a format that fits your place and your audience.

permanent.title: Permanent CoStructure cubes
permanent.intro: Permanent cubes stay at one site for a longer period – for example on an industrial area, in a courtyard or as part of an educational campus. They act as an anchor for changing exhibitions, workshops and neighbourhood formats.

formats.title: What can happen in the cube
formats.intro: CoStructure events combine different building blocks. From these elements we can assemble tailored programmes for different sites and audiences.

item1.title: Mini exhibitions
item1.body: Graphics, photos, historical documents, material samples and simple models make the history and future of a site visible – prepared in an accessible way for a broad audience.

item2.title: Workshops & labs
item2.body: Hands-on formats for building, tinkering, measuring and experimenting: from upcycling workshops to material experiments and small urban labs with maps and models.

item3.title: Talks & short inputs
item3.body: 15–30 minute inputs from research, planning, activism or art – as a starting point for topics like industrial heritage, urban change, energy or just cities.

item4.title: Walks & site tours
item4.body: The cube acts as a starting point for guided walks across the site or through the neighbourhood. On the way, stories are told, traces are shown and future scenarios are discussed.

item5.title: Open space & participation
item5.body: Idea walls, annotatable maps, small prototypes and conversation formats make it easy for neighbours, visitors and initiatives to share their perspectives.

contribute.title: Co-create the programme in the cube
contribute.intro: CoStructure lives from people sharing their knowledge, experiences and perspectives. The cube is a platform – not just a stage.
contribute.item1: You are a researcher and would like to make your work accessible.
contribute.item2: You work in planning, heritage, industry or administration and want to share insights.
contribute.item3: You are active in an initiative, association, teaching or the arts and are looking for a place to show your topics.
contribute.item4: You simply have a strong idea for a workshop, installation or conversation format in the cube.
contribute.primaryCta: I want to host something in the cube
contribute.footer: Please write a few sentences about who you are, what you would like to do and whether you want to connect to a mobile or a permanent cube.
contribute.exampleBody: “Hey, I’m a researcher at university XY and I work on the history of a nearby industrial site. I’d love to give a 20-minute input and then have a discussion with the neighbourhood. Inside the cube we could show a small mini exhibition with photos and maps.”
contribute.exampleHint: Short, concrete ideas like this help us to co-design a format that matches you, the site and the cube.

mobile1.title: Industrial heritage to touch – pop-up in an industrial yard
mobile1.meta: Mobile cube · 3 days · Former industrial site
mobile1.description: A mobile CoStructure cube turns the courtyard of a former industrial site into a small pop-up exhibition: the outside surfaces tell the story of the place, inside visitors can touch material samples, look at old plans and listen to short audio stories. Short mini tours with people who know the site accompany the programme.
mobile1.audience: Audience: neighbours, people interested in history, casual passers-by.

mobile2.title: Future lab: Your city of tomorrow
mobile2.meta: Mobile cube · 1 week · City festival / central square
mobile2.description: During the day, school classes take part in workshops on urban development, energy and circularity. In the afternoon, residents can map their ideas for the neighbourhood on maps and models. In the evening, short talks address topics such as adaptive reuse of industrial buildings or climate-resilient districts.
mobile2.audience: Audience: school classes, residents, initiatives, administration.

mobile3.title: Temporary makerspace – repair & upcycling
mobile3.meta: Mobile cube · 2 days · Courtyard / community centre
mobile3.description: The cube becomes a temporary mini makerspace: inside there are simple tools and material samples, outside an open repair and upcycling action. People bring broken everyday objects, learn repair techniques and start conversations about resources and material cycles.
mobile3.audience: Audience: neighbours, DIY community, families, anyone with broken things.

permanent1.title: Open cube day – every first Saturday
permanent1.description: On the first Saturday of each month, the cube opens without registration. Inside, a small exhibition tells the story of the site, with changing exhibits and a question wall where visitors can add their own memories. Short 20-minute tours make it easy to join.
permanent1.audience: Audience: neighbours, casual visitors, people on site.

permanent2.title: School module: Industrial heritage & future questions
permanent2.description: In a 90-minute session, the cube becomes a learning station: pupils work in small groups with maps, materials and mini models. They research how the site was used in the past and design scenarios of what it could look like in 30 years. Their results stay visible in the cube as a small exhibition.
permanent2.audience: Audience: school classes, teachers, educational partners.

permanent3.title: After-work input & exchange
permanent3.description: A relaxed after-work format with short inputs on topics such as adaptive reuse, energy, just cities or feminist perspectives on industrial heritage. Afterwards, there is time for questions and conversations in a small setting.
permanent3.audience: Audience: people living or working nearby, professionals, interested visitors.

aboutNew.title: CoStructure — explained clearly, experienced in the city
aboutNew.lead: CoStructure brings industrial heritage into everyday life — not as a museum, but as open learning and meeting places in public space. Two cube formats (permanent + mobile) and a digital map connect past, present and future: visible, low-barrier and participatory.
quickFacts: Two formats: permanent cube + mobile cube
Industrial heritage + gender lens + city as classroom

howItems.title: The permanent cube
howItems.body: A weather-proof micro place next to industrial heritage. It invites people to sit, listen and take part. Rotating content inside (posters, QR, short texts, photos) — plus outdoor seating modules for spontaneous micro-formats.

howItems.title: The mobile cube
howItems.body: A cube on wheels that travels to neighbourhoods. Side panels open and create a covered space. Ideal for pop-ups, walks, school modules or small workshops — visible, quick to set up, present where everyday life happens.

howItems.title: The map as amplifier
howItems.body: The map shows sites, status (e.g. planned/temporary/realised), reuse and thematic focus. It keeps the project accessible beyond specific times or events. Over time it can bundle stories, biographies and media modules.

howItems.title: The key idea
howItems.body: CoStructure tells industrial heritage not only as architecture and machines, but as social history: labour, everyday life, what is usually invisible. The cube is the stage in the city — the map is the context that connects everything.

aboutNew.whyProblemTitle: Industrial heritage is often told one-sided.
aboutNew.whyProblemBody: Buildings, technology and ‘great names’ are visible — while the contributions of many women and marginalised groups remain unseen. Many industrial sites also feel inaccessible, purely functional, rough, or unsafe at night — and are rarely designed as inviting places to stay.
whyApproachBullets: short, clear content instead of text walls
aboutNew.whyQuote: “Access is future: when places are open, more people dare to shape tech, design and the city.”

impactItems.title: For visitors
impactItems.body: A clear place to pause and learn — without intimidation. Heritage becomes tangible because it appears in everyday routines: a quick stop, a mini exhibit, a conversation, a hands-on moment.

impactItems.title: For neighbourhoods
impactItems.body: Activation and exchange where people usually just pass through. The cube becomes an anchor for residents, initiatives and schools — not a one-off event but a recurring, visible micro-place.

impactItems.title: For shifting perspectives
impactItems.body: A gender lens means making invisible labour visible, questioning stereotypes and opening pathways into tech & design. Not exclusive — inclusive by design, so everyone can learn together.

steps.title: Concept & content
steps.body: Goals, formats and core messages are set. Content is designed to be quickly understandable (text, visuals, optional audio/QR).

steps.title: Pilot site & partners
steps.body: Coordination with potential sites and partners (e.g. schools, initiatives, industrial heritage locations). Selection of a pilot setup for the start.

steps.title: Prototyping & implementation
steps.body: Materials, construction and modular elements are tested. In parallel, the final structure of the map and content modules is built.

steps.title: Programme start
steps.body: Launch + ongoing programme with regular formats: workshops, talks, school modules, walks and mobile pop-ups — seasonally adjusted.

aboutNew.getInvolvedBody: Know a site that could fit — or a story that should be told? Send a short message. One sentence is enough; the rest can grow from there.

faqs.q: Is this real already or still a concept?
faqs.a: The map is already usable. The cube is planned as a pilot — next steps are prototyping, site coordination and preparing the first formats.
No. Curiosity is enough. Content is designed to work for people without any background knowledge.

Because industrial heritage often makes only one perspective visible. CoStructure expands the narrative: labour, everyday life and contributions that are usually missing — and it opens access to tech & design.
By suggesting sites, stories, partnerships (school/initiative/site) or giving feedback on the map. Later, this can also become a small form.

aboutNew.footerNote: This page is intentionally scannable. Highly detailed material (budget, timeline, risk plan) works better as a download/appendix — not as long web text.
